riskOverview.businessInterruption: Business interruption caused by a system failure, leading to lost income and any additional costs incurred to mitigate damage and help the business continue
riskOverview.ransomWareExtortion: Events in which a hacker infiltrates a computer system and threatens to commit a malicious act unless a ransom fee is paid. The scope extends to extortion payments made and expenses incurred in responding to those demands.
riskOverview.regulation&Compliance: Costs resulting from fines or penalties imposed on a company by regulatory authorities. This includes legal fees associated with responding to regulatory actions.
riskOverview.thirdPartyServiceProviders: Income losses and additional costs caused by a failure of a third-party service provider. In the event that the provider's system fails or is attacked, dependent income losses and additional costs of mitigating the service failure are captured.
riskOverview.thirdPartyLiability: Covers the cost of negligent acts, errors, or omissions. Includes claims of third parties alleging failure to properly protect sensitive data stored on a computer system.
riskOverview.DataTheft&Privacy: Covers first-party costs associated with an event in which a customer's or employee's sensitive data is compromised or exposed.
riskOverview.averageExposure: The average of the 10,000 simulated years.
riskOverview.lowExposure: There is a 98% chance that the company will suffer a loss that will exceed {{exposure}} in the next year from cyber events.
riskOverview.highExposure: There is a 1% chance that the company will suffer a loss that will exceed {{exposure}} in the next year from cyber events.
pastQuantifications.overallExposure: The following graph represents the trends in the average cost over a year (including the probability-weighted impact of the extreme events). This can help to better understand the overall difference between simulations, while taking into account both tail and less severe events
pastQuantifications.lossDriversBreakdown: The following graph represents the trends in the average cost over a year (including the probability-weighted impact of the extreme events). This can help to better understand the overall difference between simulations, while taking into account both tail and less severe events.
riskOverview.averageAnnualLoss: This loss is based on the result of a Monte Carlo simulation run. After the model runs, the damage of every simulated year is summed and divided by the number of simulations. This provides visibility into the expected loss.
riskOverview.topBusinessImpactScenarios: This reflects the associated costs with scenarios that are most likely to affect your business.
riskOverview.controlsTier: This calculation reflects the status of the company's {{framework}} controls maturity, by averaging implementation levels of all known controls, where maturity ranges between {{rangeMinimum}} and {{rangeMaximum}}.
riskOverview.immediateMitigationOptions: These reflect recommendations of controls that have the largest impact on the expected loss if upgraded.
riskOverview.likelihoodOfTargetedEvents: The sum of all frequencies from all types of targeted events.
inputs.hoursToRestore: How many hours does it typically take to restore your critical business operations following a network interruption?

inputs.serviceProviders: These are third-party service providers considered critical to operating the business. They are key inputs to the model and significantly contribute to losses caused by liability claims or business interruption that fail to deliver or have an outage.
inputs.technologies: These are technologies considered critical to operating the business. They are key inputs to the model and have the most significant contribution to the resulting financial quantification.

1.title: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
1.description: Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all enterprise assets (end-user devices, including portable and mobile; network devices; non-computing/Internet of Things (IoT) devices; and servers) connected to the infrastructure physically, virtually, remotely, and those within cloud environments, to accurately know the totality of assets that need to be monitored and protected within the enterprise. This will also support identifying unauthorized and unmanaged assets to remove or remediate.

2.title: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
2.description: Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software (operating systems and applications) on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute, and that unauthorized and unmanaged software is found and prevented from installation or execution.

3.title: Data Protection
3.description: Develop processes and technical controls to identify, classify, securely handle, retain, and dispose of data.

4.title: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
4.description: Establish and maintain the secure configuration of enterprise assets (end-user devices, including portable and mobile; network devices; non-computing/IoT devices; and servers) and software (operating systems and applications).

5.title: Account Management
5.description: Use processes and tools to assign and manage authorization to credentials for user accounts, including administrator accounts, as well as service accounts, to enterprise assets and software.

6.title: Access Control Management
6.description: Use processes and tools to create, assign, manage, and revoke access credentials and privileges for user, administrator, and service accounts for enterprise assets and software.

7.title: Continuous Vulnerability Management
7.description: Develop a plan to continuously assess and track vulnerabilities on all enterprise assets within the enterprise's infrastructure, in order to remediate, and minimize, the window of opportunity for attackers. Monitor public and private industry sources for new threat and vulnerability information.

8.title: Audit Log Management
8.description: Collect, alert, review, and retain audit logs of events that could help detect, understand, or recover from an attack.

9.title: Email and Web Browser Protections
9.description: Improve protections and detections of threats from email and web vectors, as these are opportunities for attackers to manipulate human behavior through direct engagement.

10.title: Malware Defenses
10.description: Prevent or control the installation, spread, and execution of malicious applications, code, or scripts on enterprise assets.

11.title: Data Recovery
11.description: Establish and maintain data recovery practices sufficient to restore in-scope enterprise assets to a pre-incident and trusted state.

12.title: Network Infrastructure Management
12.description: Establish, implement, and actively manage (track, report, correct) network devices, in order to prevent attackers from exploiting vulnerable network services and access points.

13.title: Network Monitoring and Defense
13.description: Operate processes and tooling to establish and maintain comprehensive network monitoring and defense against security threats across the enterprise's network infrastructure and user base.

14.title: Security Awareness and Skills Training
14.description: Establish and maintain a security awareness program to influence behavior among the workforce to be security conscious and properly skilled to reduce cybersecurity risks to the enterprise.

15.title: Service Provider Management
15.description: Develop a process to evaluate service providers who hold sensitive data, or are responsible for an enterprise's critical IT platforms or processes, to ensure these providers are protecting those platforms and data appropriately.

16.title: Application Software Security
16.description: Manage the security life cycle of in-house developed, hosted, or acquired software to prevent, detect, and remediate security weaknesses before they can impact the enterprise.

17.title: Incident Response Management
17.description: Establish a program to develop and maintain an incident response capability (e.g., policies, plans, procedures, defined roles, training, and communications) to prepare, detect, and quickly respond to an attack.

18.title: Penetration Testing
18.description: Test the effectiveness and resiliency of enterprise assets through identifying and exploiting weaknesses in controls (people, processes, and technology), and simulating the objectives and actions of an attacker.

questions.title: Policies for information security
questions.description: Information security policy and topic-specific policies shall be defined, approved by management, published, communicated to and acknowledged by relevant personnel and relevant interested parties, and reviewed at planned intervals and if significant changes occur.

questions.title: Information security roles and responsibilities
questions.description: Information security roles and responsibilities shall be defined and allocated according to the organization needs.

questions.title: Segregation of duties
questions.description: Conflicting duties and conflicting areas of responsibility shall be segregated.

questions.title: Management responsibilities
questions.description: Management shall require all personnel to apply information security in accordance with the established information security policy, topic-specific policies and procedures of the organization.

questions.title: Contact with authorities
questions.description: The organization shall establish and maintain contact with relevant authorities.

questions.title: Contact with special interest groups
questions.description: The organization shall establish and maintain contact with special interest groups or other specialist security forums and professional associations.

questions.title: Threat intelligence
questions.description: Information relating to information security threats shall be collected and analysed to produce threat intelligence.

questions.title: Information security in project management
questions.description: Information security shall be integrated into project management.

questions.title: Inventory of information and other associated assets
questions.description: An inventory of information and other associated assets, including owners, shall be developed and maintained.

questions.title: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
questions.description: Rules for the acceptable use and procedures for handling information and other associated assets shall be identified, documented and implemented.

questions.title: Return of assets
questions.description: Personnel and other interested parties as appropriate shall return all the organization's assets in their possession upon change or termination of their employment, contract or agreement.

questions.title: Classification of information
questions.description: Information shall be classified according to the information security needs of the organization based on confidentiality, integrity, availability and relevant interested party requirements.

questions.title: Labelling of information
questions.description: An appropriate set of procedures for information labelling shall be developed and implemented in accordance with the information classification scheme adopted by the organization.

questions.title: Information transfer
questions.description: Information transfer rules, procedures, or agreements shall be in place for all types of transfer facilities within the organization and between the organization and other parties.

questions.title: Access control
questions.description: Rules to control physical and logical access to information and other associated assets shall be established and implemented based on business and information security requirements.

questions.title: Identity management
questions.description: The full life cycle of identities shall be managed.

questions.title: Authentication information
questions.description: Allocation and management of authentication information shall be controlled by a management process, including advising personnel on appropriate handling of authentication information.

questions.title: Access rights
questions.description: Access rights to information and other associated assets shall be provisioned, reviewed, modified and removed in accordance with the organization's topic-specific policy on and rules for access control.

questions.title: Information security in supplier relationships
questions.description: Processes and procedures shall be defined and implemented to manage the information security risks associated with the use of supplier's products or services.

questions.title: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
questions.description: Relevant information security requirements shall be established and agreed with each supplier based on the type of supplier relationship.

questions.title: Managing information security in the information and communication technology (ICT) supply chain
questions.description: Processes and procedures shall be defined and implemented to manage the information security risks associated with the ICT products and services supply chain.

questions.title: Monitoring, review and change management of supplier services
questions.description: The organization shall regularly monitor, review, evaluate and manage change in supplier information security practices and service delivery.

questions.title: Information security for use of cloud services
questions.description: Processes for acquisition, use, management and exit from cloud services shall be established in accordance with the organization's information security requirements.

questions.title: Information security incident management planning and preparation
questions.description: The organization shall plan and prepare for managing information security incidents by defining, establishing and communicating information security incident management processes, roles and responsibilities.

questions.title: Assessment and decision on information security events
questions.description: The organization shall assess information security events and decide if they are to be categorized as information security incidents.

questions.title: Response to information security incidents
questions.description: Information security incidents shall be responded to in accordance with the documented procedures.

questions.title: Learning from information security incidents
questions.description: Knowledge gained from information security incidents shall be used to strengthen and improve the information security controls.

questions.title: Collection of evidence
questions.description: The organization shall establish and implement procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition and preservation of evidence related to information security events.

questions.title: Information security during disruption
questions.description: The organization shall plan how to maintain information security at an appropriate level during disruption.

questions.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
questions.description: ICT readiness shall be planned, implemented, maintained and tested based on business continuity objectives and ICT continuity requirements.

questions.title: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
questions.description: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements relevant to information security and the organization's approach to meet these requirements shall be identified, documented and kept up to date.

questions.title: Intellectual property rights
questions.description: The organization shall implement appropriate procedures to protect intellectual property rights.

questions.title: Protection of records
questions.description: Records shall be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release.

questions.title: Privacy and protection of personal identifiable information (PII)
questions.description: The organization shall identify and meet the requirements regarding the preservation of privacy and protection of PII according to applicable laws and regulations and contractual requirements.

questions.title: Independent review of information security
questions.description: The organization's approach to managing information security and its implementation including people, processes and technologies shall be reviewed independently at planned intervals, or when significant changes occur.

questions.title: Compliance with policies, rules and standards for information security
questions.description: Compliance with the organization's information security policy, topic-specific policies, rules and standards shall be regularly reviewed.

questions.title: Documented operating procedures
questions.description: Operating procedures for information processing facilities shall be documented and made available to personnel who need them.

questions.title: Screening
questions.description: Background verification checks on all candidates to become personnel shall be carried out prior to joining the organization and on an ongoing basis taking into consideration applicable laws, regulations and ethics and be proportional to the business requirements, the classification of the information to be accessed and the perceived risks.

questions.title: Terms and conditions of employment
questions.description: The employment contractual agreements shall state the personnel's and the organization's responsibilities for information security.

questions.title: Information security awareness, education and training
questions.description: Personnel of the organization and relevant interested parties shall receive appropriate information security awareness, education and training and regular updates of the organization's information security policy, topic-specific policies and procedures, as relevant for their job function.

questions.title: Disciplinary process
questions.description: A disciplinary process shall be formalized and communicated to take actions against personnel and other relevant interested parties who have committed an information security policy violation.

questions.title: Responsibilities after termination or change of employment
questions.description: Information security responsibilities and duties that remain valid after termination or change of employment shall be defined, enforced and communicated to relevant personnel and other interested parties.

questions.title: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements
questions.description: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements reflecting the organization's needs for the protection of information shall be identified, documented, regularly reviewed and signed by personnel and other relevant interested parties.

questions.title: Remote working
questions.description: Security measures shall be implemented when personnel are working remotely to protect information accessed, processed or stored outside the organization's premises.

questions.title: Information security event reporting
questions.description: The organization shall provide a mechanism for personnel to report observed or suspected information security events through appropriate channels in a timely manner.

questions.title: Physical security perimeters
questions.description: Security perimeters shall be defined and used to protect areas that contain information and other associated assets.

questions.title: Physical entry
questions.description: Secure areas shall be protected by appropriate entry controls to ensure that only authorized personnel are allowed access.

questions.title: Securing offices, rooms and facilities
questions.description: Physical security shall be applied to offices, rooms and facilities.

questions.title: Physical security monitoring
questions.description: Physical security shall be monitored to detect potential unauthorized physical access.

questions.title: Protecting against physical and environmental threats
questions.description: Protection against physical and environmental threats, such as natural disasters and other malicious attacks, shall be designed and implemented.

questions.title: Working in secure areas
questions.description: Procedures for working in secure areas shall be designed and implemented.

questions.title: Clear desk and clear screen
questions.description: The organization shall adopt clear desk and clear screen practices to reduce the risk of unauthorized access or damage to papers, media, and information processing facilities.

questions.title: Equipment siting and protection
questions.description: Equipment shall be sited and protected to reduce the risks from environmental threats and hazards, and opportunities for unauthorized access.

questions.title: Security of assets off-premises
questions.description: Security shall be applied to assets when off-premises.

questions.title: Storage media
questions.description: Media shall be managed, controlled, transported, and disposed of to protect information from unauthorized disclosure, modification, removal, or destruction.

questions.title: Supporting utilities
questions.description: The organization shall ensure the provision of necessary supporting utilities, such as electricity, water, sewage, heating/ventilation, and air conditioning, to meet its business continuity objectives.

questions.title: Cabling security
questions.description: Power and telecommunications cabling carrying data or supporting information services shall be protected from interception, interference, or damage.

questions.title: Equipment maintenance
questions.description: Equipment shall be correctly maintained to ensure its continued availability and integrity.

questions.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
questions.description: All items of equipment containing storage media shall be verified to ensure that any sensitive data and licensed software has been removed or securely overwritten prior to disposal or re-use.

questions.title: User endpoint devices
questions.description: Controls shall be implemented to mitigate the risk of theft or loss of endpoint devices and unauthorized access to endpoint devices.

questions.title: Privileged access rights
questions.description: The allocation and use of privileged access rights shall be restricted and controlled.

questions.title: Information access restriction
questions.description: Access to information and other associated assets shall be restricted in accordance with the established access control policy.

questions.title: Access to source code
questions.description: Access to source code shall be restricted and controlled.

questions.title: Secure authentication
questions.description: Users shall be required to follow the organization's practices for secure authentication.

questions.title: Capacity management
questions.description: The use of resources shall be monitored, tuned, and projections made of future capacity requirements to ensure the required system performance.

questions.title: Protection against malware
questions.description: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malware shall be implemented, combined with appropriate user awareness.

questions.title: Management of technical vulnerabilities
questions.description: Information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used shall be obtained, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities evaluated, and appropriate measures taken to address the associated risk.

questions.title: Configuration management
questions.description: Configuration management of information systems shall be implemented to prevent accidental or deliberate unauthorized changes.

questions.title: Information deletion
questions.description: Information stored on information systems, devices, or in any other storage media shall be deleted when no longer required.

questions.title: Data masking
questions.description: Data masking shall be used in accordance with the organization's topic-specific policy on access control and data protection.

questions.title: Data leakage prevention
questions.description: Data leakage prevention measures shall be applied to systems, networks, and any other devices that process, store, or transmit sensitive information.

questions.title: Information backup
questions.description: Backup copies of information, software and systems shall be maintained and regularly tested.

questions.title: Redundancy of information processing facilities
questions.description: Information processing facilities shall be implemented with redundancy sufficient to meet availability requirements.

questions.title: Logging
questions.description: Logging shall be enabled to record user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events.

questions.title: Monitoring activities
questions.description: Information systems shall be monitored to detect anomalous behaviour and provide evidence of information security events.

questions.title: Clock synchronization
questions.description: The clocks of information processing systems shall be synchronized to a single reference time source.

questions.title: Use of privileged utility programs
questions.description: The use of utility programs that might be capable of overriding system and application controls shall be restricted and tightly controlled.

questions.title: Installation of software on operational systems
questions.description: Procedures shall be implemented to control the installation of software on operational systems.

questions.title: Networks security
questions.description: Networks and network services shall be secured, using controls such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and network segmentation.

questions.title: Security of network services
questions.description: Security mechanisms, service levels, and management requirements of all network services shall be identified and included in network service agreements.

questions.title: Segregation of networks
questions.description: Groups of information services, users, and information systems shall be segregated on networks.

questions.title: Web filtering
questions.description: The organization shall implement web filtering to restrict access to inappropriate websites.

questions.title: Use of cryptography
questions.description: Cryptographic controls shall be used to protect the confidentiality, authenticity, and integrity of information.

questions.title: Secure development life cycle
questions.description: The organization shall establish a secure development life cycle that incorporates security requirements throughout the stages of development.

questions.title: Application security requirements
questions.description: Security requirements for applications shall be defined, documented, and verified as part of the development and acquisition processes.

questions.title: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
questions.description: Principles for engineering secure systems shall be established, documented, and applied to any information system implementation efforts.

questions.title: Secure coding
questions.description: Secure coding practices shall be applied to software development.

questions.title: Security testing in development and acceptance
questions.description: Information security testing shall be carried out during the development and acceptance phases of information systems.

questions.title: Outsourced development
questions.description: The organization shall supervise and monitor the activity of outsourced system development.

questions.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
questions.description: Development, testing, and operational environments shall be separated to reduce the risks of unauthorized access or changes to the operational environment.

questions.title: Change management
questions.description: Changes to information processing facilities and systems shall be controlled.

questions.title: Test information
questions.description: Test information shall be selected carefully and protected, in accordance with the organization's information security policies.

questions.title: Protection of information systems during audit testing
questions.description: Audit tests shall be carefully planned and controlled to minimize disruptions to business processes and ensure the integrity of the information systems.

Organizational-1.title: Policies for information security
Organizational-1.description: Information security policy and topic-specific policies should be defined, approved by management, published, communicated to and acknowledged by relevant personnel and relevant interested parties, and reviewed at planned intervals and if significant changes occur.

Organizational-2.title: Information security roles and responsibilities
Organizational-2.description: Information security roles and responsibilities should be defined and allocated according to the organization needs.

Organizational-3.title: Segregation of duties
Organizational-3.description: Conflicting duties and areas of responsibility should be segregated to reduce opportunities for unauthorized or unintentional modification or misuse of the organization's assets.

Organizational-4.title: Management responsibilities
Organizational-4.description: Management should require all relevant personnel to apply information security in accordance with the established information security policy and topic-specific policies of the organization.

Organizational-5.title: Contact with authorities
Organizational-5.description: The organization should establish and maintain contact with relevant authorities.

Organizational-6.title: Contact with special interest groups
Organizational-6.description: Appropriate contacts with special interest groups or other specialist security forums and professional associations should be maintained.

Organizational-7.title: Threat intelligence
Organizational-7.description: Information on information security threats should be collected and analysed to produce threat intelligence.

Organizational-8.title: Information security in project management
Organizational-8.description: Information security should be addressed in project management, regardless of the type of the project.

Organizational-9.title: Inventory of information and other associated assets
Organizational-9.description: An inventory of information and other associated assets, including owners, should be established and maintained.

Organizational-10.title: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
Organizational-10.description: Rules for the acceptable use of information and other associated assets should be identified, documented and implemented.

Organizational-11.title: Return of assets
Organizational-11.description: Personnel and other relevant interested parties should return all of the organization's assets in their possession upon change or termination of their employment, contract or agreement.

Organizational-12.title: Classification of information
Organizational-12.description: Information should be classified according to the information security needs of the organization based on confidentiality, integrity, availability and relevant interested party requirements.

Organizational-13.title: Labelling of information
Organizational-13.description: Information should be labelled to ensure it is handled according to its classification.

Organizational-14.title: Information transfer
Organizational-14.description: Security measures should be in place to protect information during transfer.

Organizational-15.title: Access control
Organizational-15.description: Rules to control physical and logical access to information and other associated assets should be established and implemented based on business and information security requirements.

Organizational-16.title: Identity management
Organizational-16.description: The organization should implement identity management processes to ensure that only authorized users have access to information and resources.

Organizational-17.title: Authentication information
Organizational-17.description: Authentication information should be securely managed and protected to ensure its confidentiality and integrity.

Organizational-18.title: Access rights
Organizational-18.description: Access rights to information and other associated assets should be provisioned, reviewed, modified, and removed in accordance with the organization's topic-specific policy on and rules for access control.

Organizational-19.title: Information security in supplier relationships
Organizational-19.description: Information security requirements should be established and managed with suppliers.

Organizational-20.title: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
Organizational-20.description: Supplier agreements should include requirements to address information security risks.

Organizational-21.title: Managing information security in the ICT supply chain)
Organizational-21.description: The organization should manage information security risks associated with its ICT supply chain.

Organizational-22.title: Monitoring, review, and change management of supplier services
Organizational-22.description: Supplier services should be monitored, reviewed, and managed to ensure that information security requirements are met.

Organizational-23.title: Information security for use of cloud services
Organizational-23.description: Security measures should be implemented to protect information when using cloud services.

Organizational-24.title: Information security incident management
Organizational-24.description: Processes should be in place to manage information security incidents.

Organizational-25.title: Assessment and decision on information security events
Organizational-25.description: The organization should assess information security events and decide if they are to be categorized as information security incidents.

Organizational-26.title: Response to information security incidents
Organizational-26.description: Information security incidents should be responded to in accordance with the documented procedures.

Organizational-27.title: Learning from information security incidents
Organizational-27.description: Knowledge gained from analysing information security incidents should be used to strengthen and improve the information security controls.

Organizational-28.title: Collection of evidence
Organizational-28.description: The organization should define and apply procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition, and preservation of information, which can serve as evidence.

Organizational-29.title: Information security during disruption
Organizational-29.description: The organization should plan how to maintain information security at an appropriate level during disruption.

Organizational-30.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
Organizational-30.description: ICT readiness should be planned, implemented, maintained and tested based on business continuity objectives and ICT continuity requirements.

Organizational-31.title: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
Organizational-31.description: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements relevant to information security and the organization's approach to meet these requirements should be identified, documented and kept up to date.

Organizational-32.title: Intellectual property rights
Organizational-32.description: The organization should implement appropriate procedures to ensure compliance with legal, statutory, regulatory, and contractual requirements related to intellectual property rights.

Organizational-33.title: Protection of records
Organizational-33.description: Records should be protected from loss, destruction, falsification, unauthorized access and unauthorized release.

Organizational-34.title: Privacy and protection of personally identifiable information
Organizational-34.description: The organization should implement procedures to ensure the protection of personally identifiable information (PII) in line with relevant legislation and regulation.

Organizational-35.title: Independent review of information security
Organizational-35.description: The organizations approach to managing information security and its implementation, including people, processes, and technologies, should be reviewed independently at planned intervals or when significant changes occur.

Organizational-36.title: Compliance with policies, rules, and standards for information security
Organizational-36.description: Compliance with the organization's information security policy, rules, standards, and any other security requirements should be reviewed and audited regularly.

Organizational-37.title: Documented operating procedures
Organizational-37.description: Operating procedures for information processing facilities should be documented and made available to personnel who need them.

People-1.title: Screening
People-1.description: Background verification checks on all candidates to become personnel should be carried out prior to joining the organization and on an ongoing basis taking into consideration applicable laws, regulations and ethics and be proportional to the business requirements, the classification of the information to be accessed and the perceived risks.

People-2.title: Terms and conditions of employment
People-2.description: The employment contractual agreements should state the personnel's and the organization's responsibilities for information security.

People-3.title: Information security awareness, education and training
People-3.description: Personnel of the organization and relevant interested parties should receive appropriate information security awareness, education and training and regular updates of the organization's information security policy, topic-specific policies and procedures, as relevant for their job function

People-4.title: Disciplinary process
People-4.description: A disciplinary process should be formalized and communicated to take actions against personnel and other relevant interested parties who have committed an information security policy violation.

People-5.title: Responsibilities after termination or change of employment
People-5.description: Information security responsibilities and duties that remain valid after termination or change of employment should be defined, enforced and communicated to relevant personnel and other interested parties.

People-6.title: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements
People-6.description: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements reflecting the organization's needs for the protection of information should be identified, documented, regularly reviewed and signed by personnel and other relevant interested parties.

People-7.title: Remote working
People-7.description: Security measures should be implemented when personnel are working remotely to protect information accessed, processed or stored outside the organization's premises.

People-8.title: Information security event reporting
People-8.description: The organization should provide a mechanism for personnel to report observed or suspected information security events through appropriate channels in a timely manner.

Physical-1.title: Physical security perimeters
Physical-1.description: Security perimeters should be defined and used to protect areas that contain information and other associated assets.

Physical-2.title: Physical entry
Physical-2.description: Secure areas should be protected by appropriate entry controls and access points.

Physical-3.title: Securing offices, rooms and facilities
Physical-3.description: Physical security for offices, rooms and facilities should be designed and implemented.

Physical-4.title: Physical security monitoring
Physical-4.description: Premises should be continuously monitored for unauthorized physical access.

Physical-5.title: Protecting against physical and environmental threats
Physical-5.description: Protection against physical and environmental threats, such as natural disasters and other intentional or unintentional physical threats to infrastructure should be designed and implemented.

Physical-6.title: Working in secure areas
Physical-6.description: Security measures for working in secure areas should be designed and implemented.

Physical-7.title: Clear desk and clear screen policy
Physical-7.description: Clear desk rules for papers and removable storage media and clear screen rules for information processing facilities should be defined and appropriately enforced.

Physical-8.title: Equipment siting and protection
Physical-8.description: Equipment should be sited securely and protected.

Physical-10.title: Storage media
Physical-10.description: Storage media should be managed through their life cycle of acquisition, use, transportation and disposal in accordance with the organization's classification scheme and handling requirements.

Physical-11.title: Supporting utilities
Physical-11.description: Information processing facilities should be protected from power failures and other disruptions caused by failures in supporting utilities.

Physical-12.title: Cabling security
Physical-12.description: Cables carrying power, data or supporting information services should be protected from interception, interference or damage.

Physical-13.title: Equipment maintenance
Physical-13.description: Equipment should be maintained correctly to ensure availability, integrity and confidentiality of information.

Physical-14.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
Physical-14.description: Items of equipment containing storage media should be verified to ensure that any sensitive data and licensed software has been removed or securely overwritten prior to disposal or re-use.

Technological-1.title: User endpoint devices
Technological-1.description: Information stored on, processed by or accessible via user endpoint devices should be protected.

Technological-2.title: Privileged access rights
Technological-2.description: The allocation and use of privileged access rights should be restricted and managed.

Technological-3.title: Information access restriction
Technological-3.description: Access to information and other associated assets should be restricted in accordance with the established topic-specific policy on access control.

Technological-4.title: Access to source code
Technological-4.description: Read and write access to source code, development tools and software libraries should be appropriately managed.

Technological-5.title: Secure authentication
Technological-5.description: Secure authentication technologies and procedures should be implemented based on information access restrictions and the topic-specific policy on access control.

Technological-6.title: Capacity management
Technological-6.description: The use of resources should be monitored, tuned, and projections made of future capacity requirements to ensure the required system performance.

Technological-7.title: Protection from malware
Technological-7.description: Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against malware should be implemented, combined with appropriate user awareness.

Technological-8.title: Management of technical vulnerabilities
Technological-8.description: Information about technical vulnerabilities of information systems being used should be obtained in a timely fashion, the organization's exposure to such vulnerabilities should be evaluated, and appropriate measures should be taken to address the associated risk.

Technological-9.title: Configuration management
Technological-9.description: Configuration items should be identified, and baselines of configurations should be established and maintained.

Technological-10.title: Information deletion
Technological-10.description: Information stored on information systems, devices, or media should be securely deleted when no longer required.

Technological-11.title: Data masking
Technological-11.description: Data masking should be used in production and non-production environments where appropriate to limit the exposure of sensitive data.

Technological-12.title: Data leakage prevention
Technological-12.description: Data leakage prevention measures should be implemented to detect and prevent unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information.

Technological-13.title: Information backup
Technological-13.description: Backup copies of information, software, and system images should be taken and tested regularly in accordance with an agreed backup policy.

Technological-14.title: Redundancy of information processing facilities
Technological-14.description: Information processing facilities should be redundant to ensure availability and resilience.

Technological-15.title: Logging
Technological-15.description: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults, and information security events should be produced, kept, and regularly reviewed.

Technological-16.title: Monitoring activities
Technological-16.description: Systems and networks should be monitored to detect anomalies and potential security events.

Technological-17.title: Clock synchronization
Technological-17.description: The clocks of information processing systems used by the organization should be synchronized to approved time sources.

Technological-18.title: Use of privileged utility programs
Technological-18.description: The use of utility programs that can be capable of overriding system and application controls should be restricted and tightly controlled.

Technological-19.title: Installation of software on operational systems
Technological-19.description: Procedures and measures should be implemented to securely manage software installation on operational systems.

Technological-20.title: Networks security
Technological-20.description: Networks and network devices should be secured, managed and controlled to protect information in systems and applications.

Technological-21.title: Security of network services
Technological-21.description: Security mechanisms, service levels and service requirements of network services should be identified, implemented and monitored.

Technological-22.title: Segregation of networks
Technological-22.description: Groups of information services, users and information systems should be segregated in the organization's networks.

Technological-23.title: Web filtering
Technological-23.description: Access to external websites should be managed to reduce exposure to malicious content.

Technological-24.title: Use of cryptography
Technological-24.description: Rules for the effective use of cryptography, including cryptographic key management, should be defined and implemented.

Technological-25.title: Secure development life cycle
Technological-25.description: Rules for secure development of software and systems should be established and applied.

Technological-26.title: Application security requirements
Technological-26.description: Information security requirements should be identified, specified and approved when developing or acquiring applications.

Technological-27.title: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
Technological-27.description: Principles for engineering secure systems should be established, documented, maintained and applied to any information system development activities.

Technological-28.title: Secure coding
Technological-28.description: Secure coding principles should be applied to software development.

Technological-29.title: Security testing in development and acceptance
Technological-29.description: Security testing processes should be defined and implemented in the development life cycle.

Technological-30.title: Outsourced development
Technological-30.description: The organization should direct, monitor and review the activities related to outsourced system development.

Technological-31.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
Technological-31.description: Development, testing and production environments should be separated and secured.

Technological-32.title: Change management
Technological-32.description: Changes to information processing facilities and information systems should be subject to change management procedures.

Technological-33.title: Test information
Technological-33.description: Test information should be appropriately selected, protected and managed.

Technological-34.title: Protection of information systems during audit testing
Technological-34.description: Audit tests and other assurance activities involving assessment of operational systems should be planned and agreed between the tester and appropriate management.

transparency.crimzon.description: CRIMZONs™ (Cyber Risk Impact Zones) were established to provide an easy to use open framework to measure and understand cyber risk exposure. Analysis has shown a significant correlation between companies from the same location and industry tending to use the same third-party service providers and technologies, leaving them exposed to corresponding cyber attacks.
limitedUser.recommendations: Upgrade to fully understand how you can reduce your risk
limitedUser.totalExposure: Upgrade to get insight on your yearly risk broken down by probability and cost
limitedUser.lossBreakdown: Upgrade to see the breakdown of components that contribute to your overall loss
limitedUser.highExposure: Upgrade to see your High Exposure loss
limitedUser.byScenario.contingent_bi.tex: Losses caused by a failure in a third party provider or losses sustained due to a failure or attack to a network provider's system.
limitedUser.byScenario.liability.title: Third Party Liability
limitedUser.byScenario.liability.text: Losses incurred from negligent acts, errors, or omissions, including failure to properly protect sensitive data stored on a computer system.
limitedUser.byScenario.privacy.title: Data Theft & Privacy
limitedUser.byScenario.privacy.text: Losses derived from compromised or exposed customer data.
limitedUser.byScenario.regulatory.title: Regulation & Compliance
limitedUser.byScenario.regulatory.text: Regulatory requirements are the most important inputs to the model. They are key inputs to the model and have the most significant contribution to the resulting financial quantification.Losses due to fines or penalties imposed on a firm by regulatory agencies, including legal costs associated with response to a regulatory proceeding.

integrationModal.description.2: was added to your organization and Kovrr is collecting data on the company's assets.
integrationModal.description.3: Additionally, you can automatically populate data related to your company assets with our integration tool.

integrationPage.modalDescription1: Kovrr integrates with CMDB to gather internal customer data, including information on assets, technologies, services, vulnerabilities, and malware infections. This enriched dataset enhances Sphere, enabling a more sophisticated understanding and modeling of your organization's attack surfaces.
integrationPage.modalDescription2: Assets are grouped into Asset Group objects based on various parameters like device tags and IP gateway. These groups are mutually exclusive to prevent double-counting asset risk in Kovrr's model.
integrationPage.successDescription: Auto generated sphere will soon be available.

crowdstrike.title: Integrate with CrowdStrike for automatic sphere creation
crowdstrike.description1: The Sphere data will be populated by querying the CrowdStrike API to retrieve endpoint details.
crowdstrike.description2: Before proceeding, please ensure that the user associated with the Client ID and Client Secret has the necessary read permissions for the required module: 'Hosts'.
crowdstrike.description3: Furthermore, we recommend configuring read permissions for additional modules to enable Kovrr to access enhanced data. These modules include 'Spotlight Vulnerabilities', 'Host Groups', 'Discover', 'Incidents', and 'Detections'.

bitsight.title: Integrate with BitSight for automatic sphere creation
bitsight.description1: The Sphere data will be populated by accessing the BitSight Companies API, under which several different endpoints are queried in order to collect asset and company data.
bitsight.description2:
Before proceeding, please ensure that the user associated with the API token has read permissions for all the required endpoints:
'Assets', 'Findings', 'Company Details', and 'Company Providers'.

tanium.title: Integrate with Tanium for automatic sphere creation
tanium.description1: The Sphere data will be populated by querying the Tanium API to retrieve endpoint details.
tanium.description2: Before proceeding, please ensure the validity of the URL, and that the user associated with the API token has read permissions for the required module: 'Risk'.
tanium.description3: Furthermore, we recommend configuring read permissions for additional modules to enable Kovrr to access enhanced data. These modules include: 'Comply', 'Patch', 'Enforce', and 'Reveal'.
tanium.taniumUrlFormat: The URL format for Tanium cloud installation is https://<customername>-api.cloud.tanium.com. In an on-premise installation, the url is custom and defined by the user.

servicenow.title: Integrate with ServiceNow for automatic sphere creation
servicenow.description1: The Sphere data will be populated by querying the ServiceNow Table API.
servicenow.description2: We recommend configuring read permissions for several ServiceNow applications to enable Kovrr to access enhanced data. These applications include 'Vulnerability Response', and 'Application Portfolio Management'.
servicenow.servicenowUrlFormat: The URL format for ServiceNow url is https://<customername>.service-now.com.

qualys.title: Integrate with Qualys for automatic sphere creation
qualys.description1: Assets and vulnerabilities are imported through the Hosts and Hosts Detections API endpoints in Qualys. In addition, data on asset groups is retrieved through the Asset Groups API endpoint.
qualys.description2: Before proceeding, please ensure that the user associated with the credentials has read permissions for the required modules: 'Host', 'Host Detection', and 'Asset Groups'.
qualys.qualysUrlFormat: The URL format for Qualys url is https://qualysapi.<this can change>.com. (some APIs also have .com.au/ .co.uk etc).

securityscorecard.title: Integrate with Security Scorecard for automatic sphere creation
securityscorecard.description1: The Sphere data will be populated by querying the Security Scorecard API to retrieve endpoint details.
securityscorecard.description2: Before proceeding, please ensure that the api key associated with the API key has the necessary read permissions
securityscorecard.companiesNotFound: No companies found. To complete the process make sure you have companies associated with the portfolio.

tenable.title: Integrate with Tenable.io for automatic sphere creation
tenable.description1:
The Sphere data will be populated by accessing API endpoints in Tenable.io.
Assets and vulnerabilities are imported through the Export Assets and Export Vulnerabilities
tenable.description2: Before proceeding, please ensure that the user associated with the credentials has read permissions for the required endpoints: 'Export Assets', 'Export Vulnerabilities', and 'Export Compliance'.

Highlights.maximumDescription: There is a 1% chance that the company will suffer losses derived from third party cyber risk that will exceed {{amount}} in the next year.
Highlights.mediumDescription: This loss is based on the result of a Monte Carlo simulation that only took into account damages resulting from third party risk. After the model runs, the third party damage of every simulated year is summed and divided by the number of simulations. This provides visibility into the expected loss.
Highlights.minimumDescription: There is a 98% chance that the company will suffer losses derived from third party cyber risk that will exceed {{amount}} in the next year.

criticality.highlightedText.default: the criticality of your cloud asset groups is {{differenceFullText}}
criticality.highlightedText.cloudZero: the criticality of your cloud asset groups is 0% while the criticality of your infrastructure and employee endpoints asset groups is {{percentage}}.
criticality.highlightedText.otherZero: the criticality of your cloud asset groups is {{percentage}} while the criticality of your infrastructure and employee endpoints asset groups is 0%.
criticality.highlightedText.bothZero: the criticality of both your cloud asset groups, and the infrastructure and employee endpoints asset groups is 0%.
criticality.restOfText.equal: compared to infrastructure asset groups. The severity of events associated with third party service providers may therefore be as high as other types of events.
criticality.restOfText.notEqual: compared to infrastructure and employee endpoints asset groups. This may lead to {{criticalityDiffEffect}} in severity of events associated with third party service providers.
criticality.restOfText.cloudZero: This may lead to a decrease in the severity of events associated with third-party service providers.
criticality.restOfText.otherZero: This may lead to an increase in the severity of events associated with third-party service providers.
criticality.restOfText.bothZero: The severity of events associated with third party service providers may therefore be as high as other types of events.

numberOfRecords.highlightedText.otherZero: {{numOfRecords}} data records are stored in your cloud asset groups, while 0 records are stored in your infrastructure asset groups.
numberOfRecords.highlightedText.bothZero: The number of data records stored both in your cloud asset groups and in the infrastructure asset groups is 0.
numberOfRecords.restOfText.equal: compared to infrastructure asset groups. The severity of events associated with third party service providers may therefore be as high as other types of events.
numberOfRecords.restOfText.notEqual: compared to infrastructure asset groups. This may lead to {{numOfRecordsDiffEffect}} in severity of events associated with third party service providers.
numberOfRecords.restOfText.cloudZero: This may lead to a decrease in the severity of events associated with third-party service providers.
numberOfRecords.restOfText.otherZero: This may lead to an increase in the severity of events associated with third-party service providers.
numberOfRecords.restOfText.bothZero: The severity of events associated with third party service providers may therefore be as high as other types of events.

The specific vendors used by the company affect the probability of the company experiencing a third party event. Each vendor has a failure probability score that is determined by Kovrr's threat intelligence data which takes into account thousands of past cyber events and claims data. Higher vendor scores imply a higher chance of the company experiencing a third party event and a higher financial impact.
insights.security.title: Security
insights.security.description: The security controls a company applies to its asset groups may affect the risk probability of an attack and severity of the impact of the attack. This is also applicable for third party risks. For example: if your company's implementation of the control 'Incident Response and Management' is high, it can decrease the severity of related events.

thirdParty.table.tooltip.likelihood: This figure depicts the likelihood of your company to experience losses derived from third party risk involving the specific product.
thirdParty.table.tooltip.averageYearlyLo: This figure depicts the average annual loss of your company from experiencing losses derived from third party risk involving the specific product.
thirdParty.emptyState.title: Sorry, we have nothing to show.
thirdParty.mainPage.title: Vendors Analysis
thirdParty.emptyState.description:
The simulation resulted in no financial damage derived from a third party. It might be due to your company's low risk in this zone. 
 This also might occur if there are no cloud asset groups in your company sphere.
thirdParty.frequencyScore.title: Vendor Frequency Score
thirdParty.frequencyScore.description: Vendors are assigned a score based on their likelihood to experience an event. The company's exposure to third party risk is calculated by averaging the vendor scores.
thirdParty.resultsExplained: The company's third party risk is calculated by taking into account events solely involving third party service providers. This includes events occurring in the company caused by an exploitation of a provider weakness as well as events effecting the provider that can impact the company. Attritional events are excluded from this calculation.
thirdParty.eventTypesBreakdown.title: Event Types Breakdown
thirdParty.eventTypesBreakdown.subtitle: Based on Average Annual Loss
